sec.title: Purpose
sec.p: This study was to evaluate the efficacy of soft tissue reconstruction using synthetic mesh and a medial gastrocnemius flap in patients who underwent proximal tibial hemiarthroplasty after resection of proximal tibial bone sarcomas.

sec.title: Methods
sec.p: A retrospective cohort study was conducted on 102 skeletally immature children (58 males, 44 females) who underwent proximal tibial Hemiarthroplasty between January 2005 and December 2023. The most common diagnoses were osteosarcoma (95%), Ewing’s sarcoma (4%), and chondrosarcoma (1%). The mean age was 11 years (7–14 years) and the mean follow-up was 85 months (12–233 months). We reported complications according to the modified Henderson classification. The functional outcomes were evaluated by Musculoskeletal Tumour Society Score (MSTS-93) and the Toronto Extremity Salvage Score (TESS).

sec.title: Results
sec.p: Patients in the combined reconstruction group had higher MSTS-93 and TESS scores (MSTS-93, 83% versus 72%, p = 0.023; TESS, 85% versus 74%, p = 0.041). The mean 2-year postoperative Insall–Salvati ratio (ISR), the Blackburne–Peel index (BPI), and the Caton–Deschamps index (CDI) for patients who underwent combined reconstruction were 1.18 ± 0.32, 0.98 ± 0.22, and 1.21 ± 0.28, respectively. While, The mean 2-year postoperative ISR, BPI, and CDI of patients without combined reconstruction were 1.42 ± 0.39, 1.25 ± 0.29, and 1.61 ± 0.41, respectively (p < 0.05). The combined reconstruction group had a lower mean extensor lag (4.3° versus 11.3°, p < 0.001). In total, 33 patients had at least one complication and 27 patients underwent surgical revision, including 13 infections, 8 local recurrences, 3 soft tissue failures, 2 aseptic loosening, and 1 implant failure. The combined reconstruction group had a lower rate of knee dislocation (2.7% versus 21.4%, p = 0.002).

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: Soft tissue reconstruction of the proximal tibia using synthetic mesh combined with a medial gastrocnemius flap improves the postoperative efficacy of tumor-related proximal hemiarthroplasty and is expected to reduce the incidence of postoperative knee dislocation and periprosthetic infection.

sec.title: Level of evidence
sec.p: Level III case control study.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: The proximal tibia is the second most common site for primary bone sarcomas, with 20–30% of conventional osteosarcomas occurring here [1]. Proximal tibial sarcoma resection is most commonly reconstructed with endoprostheses, which provide immediate stability and the fastest weight-bearing. However, the epiphyses on both sides of the knee joint are the most important part of the lower limb for longitudinal growth, accounting for more than two-thirds of lower limb growth [2]. Conventional megaprosthesis reconstruction requires resection of the femoral and tibial epiphyses, which can lead to significant leg length discrepancy (LLD) in skeletally immature patients [3]. The proximal tibial Hemiarticular endoprosthesis was first used in our center in 2005, and in our previous study we described the clinical results of proximal tibial hemiarthroplasty, which preserves the normal distal femoral epiphysis and reduces the lower length discrepancy [4].

However, proximal tibial hemiarthroplasty continues to be associated with knee dislocation and limited extension function [5–8]. Owing to the resection of the periprosthetic ligaments of the knee and previous literature has described multiple strategies to reconstruct soft tissue for extensor function. The ideal reconstruction method of the extensor device remains controversial, and extensor repair methods include direct repair, allograft tissue repair, synthetic ligament repair, and mesh repair [9]. Some studies on soft tissue reconstruction of the proximal tibia have used synthetic mesh wrapped prostheses to facilitate tendon reattachment, resulting in improved extensor function. However, most of the current studies are small case series or case reports [10–12]. Therefore, we aim to compare the outcomes of synthetic mesh combined with medial gastrocnemius flap in the extensor reconstruction in proximal tibial hemiarthroplasty through a case–control study.

We reviewed 20 years of experience using hemiarthroplasty to treat bone defects after resection of proximal tibial osteosarcoma in skeletally immature patients. With this study, we sought to answer the following questions of whether patients who underwent reconstruction with a mesh combined medial gastrocnemius muscle flap (1) had better limb function, (2) had improved knee mobility and extensor function, or (3) had lower complication rates.

sec.title: Materials and methods
sec.p: With institutional review board approval, we retrospectively analyzed the medical records of all patients who underwent Hemiarthroplasty after resection of primary osteosarcoma of the proximal tibia collected at our center between 2005 and 2023. Patient data were prospectively collected and retrieved from the institution’s sarcoma database. We identified 883 patients with immature tibial bone from the institutional database, of whom 102 underwent hemiarthroplasty after resection of primary osteosarcoma of the tibia.

Patient details are shown in Table 1. We considered 743 patients with primary malignant bone tumors to be potentially eligible. Of those, 71 patients were excluded because they underwent amputation. Meanwhile, 562 patients were excluded joint-preserving endoprosthetic reconstruction, recycled autografts, or extraarticular resection, leaving 110 who met the inclusion criteria for this study. Of those, 8 patients were lost to follow-up, leaving 102 patients for analysis in this study (Figure. 1). There were 58 males and 44 females. The mean age at surgery was 11 years (range 7–14 years) and the average follow-up time was 85 months (12–233 months). The mean reconstruction length was 15 cm. 98% (100 cases) of the patients received neoadjuvant or adjuvant chemotherapy, and 12% (12 cases) received neoadjuvant or adjuvant radiotherapy. At the last follow-up, 74% (75 cases) of the patients showed no signs of disease, 8% (8 cases) were alive with disease, 18% (18 cases) had died of disease, and 1% (1 case) died of other causes. sec.title: Surgical procedure
sec.p: Previous studies have described the general surgery and procedural details (Figure. 2)[4]. All surgeries in both groups were performed by experienced oncological orthopedists (LW, ZQ, and NX). After the tumor is entirely removed, the distal tibia is reamed. Then, two or three sutures (No.5 EXCEL MB66, Ethibond) were passed through the reconstructed hole on the underside of the tibial spacer and sutured to the remaining cruciate ligament. The spacer was fixed to the distal femur with a knot at the bottom of the spacer to reconstruct the cruciate ligament. A double-layer polypropylene artificial patch (Bard® Soft Mesh, USA) was taken and sutured to the remaining joint capsule and lateral collateral ligament with sutures (No.2 EXCEL X519, Ethibond). The proximal tibial prosthesis (Lida Kang, Beijing, China) was installed and fixed with bone cement. Depending on the local soft tissue conditions, the length of the prosthesis can be 1.0–1.5 cm longer than the resection length. Install the tibial prosthesis spacer onto the prosthesis at a 90° knee flexion. The knee is placed in an extended position, the prosthesis is tightly wrapped with an artificial patch, and the prosthesis is fixed by suturing the prosthesis to the reserved hole for fixing the patellar ligament and making the patch integral with the endoprosthesis. The patellar tendon is sutured to the anterior tibial patch. The medial head muscle flap of the gastrocnemius muscle is transferred to cover the front of the endoprosthesis.

Postoperatively, the leg is immobilized in knee extension for 6–8 weeks using a long leg cast posterior support or a restrictive brace. The isometric muscle contractions were performed during the immobilization period. The patients started passive activities under the supervision of a physiotherapist, and after starting to walk, they were required to wear a support brace Limiting the lateral movement of the knee, ensuring that the knee could only be flexed and extended. Patients were asked to report to the clinic for follow-up visits every 3 months for the first year, every 6 months after 2–5 years, and annually after 5 years. Conventional anteroposterior, lateral and full-length conventional radiographs of both lower limbs were routinely taken.

sec.title: Outcomes
sec.p: Our primary study endpoints are function scores and extensor function. Our secondary study endpoints are complication rates. At the final follow-up, 89 patients who had retained the proximal tibial hemiarthroplasty and had been followed up for ≥ 2 years underwent functional assessment. The functional outcomes are assessed using the Musculoskeletal Tumor Society (MSTS-93) score and the Toronto Extremity Salvage Score (TESS). Patellar Height is determined on a lateral X-ray taken at 30° of flexion using the Insall–Salvati ratio (ISR), the Blackburne–Peel index (BPI) and the Caton–Deschamps index (CDI). Two researchers (LZ, FD) independently examined the ISR, BPI, CDI, extensor lag, and range of motion of the knee (Figure. 3). A high patella is defined as a CDI ≥ 1.2, and a low patella is defined as a CDI ≤ 0.8. A BlackBurne–Peel index > 1.0 indicates a high patella, and < 0.5 indicates a low patella. The ISR is the ratio of the patellar tendon length (TL) to the patellar length (PL). A value between 0.8 and 1.2 is considered normal and indicates a normal patella. When the ISR is less than 0.8, it is defined as a low patella. When the ISR is less than 0.8, it is defined as a low patella. The range of motion (ROM) of the knee joint is assessed using a goniometer. Loss of active extension of the knee joint from full extension to the baseline is considered as extension lag. Extension lag > 0 is considered clinically significant. All complications were recorded according to the modified Henderson classification [13]. Endoprosthesis removal-free survival is defined as the time from implantation to removal or replacement of the prosthesis’s main components for any reason.

sec.title: Statistical analysis
sec.p: Descriptive data is presented as mean ± standard deviation or as numbers and percentages. The normal distribution of the data is checked using the Kolmogorov–Smirnov test. The mean values of two groups are compared using the paired t test or its nonparametric counterpart (Wilcoxon signed-rank test). The mean values of two groups are compared using the independent t test or its nonparametric counterpart (Mann–Whitney U test). A two-sided p-value < 0.05 was considered significant. Statistical analysis was performed using the Statistical Package for the Social Science (SPSS) software version 26.0 (SPSS Inc., Chicago, IL, USA) and GraphPad Prism software version 10 (GraphPad Software, San Diego, California, USA).

sec.title: Endoprosthesis survival and complications
sec.p: We did not observe a difference in prosthesis survival between the two groups (9.4% versus 10.7%, p > 0.05). In the combined reconstruction group, there were seven patients who had their prosthesis removed, including four cases of amputation after local recurrence, one case of amputation owing to deep infection and two cases of prosthesis removal after infection. In the control group, there were three patients who had their prosthesis removed, including two cases of amputation after local recurrence and one case of prosthesis removal after infection.

In total, 33 patients had 35 complications, and 27 of them underwent revision surgery (Table 2). The most common complications were infection (13%, 13/102) and soft tissue failure (11%, 11/102), followed by local recurrence (8%, 8/102), aseptic loosening (2%, 2/102), and implant failure (1%, 1/102). The combined reconstruction group had a lower rate of knee dislocation (2.7% versus 21.4%, p = 0.002) and local infection (8.1% versus 25.0%, p = 0.022). However, we did not find a difference in the incidence of other types of complications. After controlling for variables such as age and chemotherapy, we found that a history of previous surgery and not using the medial gastrocnemius muscle flap for reconstruction were independent risk factors for knee subluxation (Table 3). sec.title: Functional outcomes
sec.p:
At the last follow-up, 89 patients who retained a proximal tibial hemiarticular endoprosthesis were assessed for functional scores (Figure. 4). The average MSTS score for patients in the combined reconstruction group was 83 ± 10% (range: 66–97%), and 85 ± 9% (range: 65–100%) for TESS, and control group was 72 ± 13% (range: 51–91%), and 74 ± 12% (range: 54–97%) for TESS, respectively (Table 4, p < 0.05). Pain and emotional acceptance scores ranged from 4 to 5, and function, support, walking and gait scores ranged from 2 to 5 (Figure. 5). We found no significant differences between the two groups in pain (p = 0.326), emotional acceptance (p = 0.397), support (p = 0.543) or walking (p = 0.235). However, patients with combined reconstruction had higher scores for function and gait (Table 4, p < 0.05). Table 4

sec.title: Knee mobility and extensor function
sec.p: There was no statistically significant difference between the two groups in preoperative ISR, BPI, and CDI (p > 0.05, Table 4). The mean 2-year postoperative ISR, BPI, and CDI for patients who underwent combined reconstruction were 1.18 ± 0.32, 0.98 ± 0.22, and 1.21 ± 0.28, respectively. Meanwhile, the mean 2-year postoperative ISR, BPI, and CDI of patients without combined reconstruction were 1.42 ± 0.39, 1.25 ± 0.29, and 1.61 ± 0.41, respectively. Patellar height was significantly lower in patients who underwent combined reconstruction compared with those who without combined reconstruction (Table 4, p < 0.05).

The mean extensor lag in the combined reconstruction group was 4.3 ± 1.2°, while the mean extensor lag in the control group was 11.3 ± 5.8° (p < 0.001). The mean active knee joint range of motion of the combined reconstruction group was 95 ± 19° (range: 60–145°), while the mean active of the control group was 77 ± 22° (range: 45–120°, p = 0.012). sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: Proximal tibial hemiarthroplasty is a rare reconstruction method, mainly seen in Asian countries [4–8]. This reconstruction method can preserve the distal femoral growth plate and reduce the degree of leg length discrepancy. However, because all the stabilizing structures around the knee joint are removed and there is no hinge structure, the proximal tibial hemiarthroplasty places higher demands on the reconstruction of knee stability. However, there is currently no one optimal soft tissue reconstruction method [10–12]. We propose a standardized reconstruction method using a synthetic mesh combined with an medial gastrocnemius flap for soft tissue reconstruction to improve the knee function of the proximal tibial hemiarthroplasty and reduce the complication rate (especially knee dislocation and infection). To the best of our knowledge, this is the largest retrospective study focusing on the soft tissue reconstruction of proximal tibial hemiarthroplasty in skeletally immature patients [4–8].

According to previous studies, soft tissue failure (knee dislocation) is the most common mechanical complication of proximal tibial hemiarthroplasty (Table. 5) [6, 7]. Chung et al. reported a knee dislocation rate of 23.1% (3/13), which is significantly higher than that of hinged arthroplasty [6]. Our study showed a knee dislocation rate of 2.7% in the combined reconstruction group, which is similar to the previously reported dislocation rate in the hinged joint reconstruction group (1–4%) [1]. We believe that several factors have improved the dislocation rate. First, we used ETHIBOND non-absorbable sutures to reconstruct the cruciate ligaments, which can provide sufficient biomechanical strength [14]. Zan et al. reported the application of the Ligament Advanced Strengthening System (LARS) to reconstruct the cruciate ligament and internal and external collateral ligaments in eight patients who underwent distal femoral hemiarthroplasty, and no knee dislocations were noted, with a mean MSTS-93 score of 81% [15]. However, the technique requires the creation of a tunnel for fixation, which has the potential to interfere with epiphyseal growth, which limits further application of the technique. Second, we sutured the medial and lateral collateral ligaments and patellar tendon to a polypropylene mesh, which is conducive to the growth of fibrous connective tissue and the formation of a soft tissue patch. Finally, we used sutures to fix the medial gastrocnemius flap to the anterior part of the patellar tendon and the surrounding fascia, which further strengthens the anterior stability of the knee joint.Figure. 1.

Consistent with previous studies, our medial gastrocnemius flap reconstruction of the proximal tibia and extensor mechanism provided good functional results. Jentzsch et al. found that high patellar height was associated with extensor lag, increased flexion and a poorer MSTS score [14]. We found that both the MSTS and TESS scores improved in the combined reconstruction group, and this improvement was accompanied by a decrease in patellar height and extensor lag. Extensor lag is a common complication of proximal tibial reconstruction [6]. Grimer et al. reported an average extensor lag of 30° (0–90°) in 151 patients who underwent prosthetic reconstruction [16]. We believe that reconstructing the extensor is necessary to improve knee range of motion and function. In this study, we fixed the remaining patellar tendon into the hole in the anterior part of the tibia and sutured the edge of the flap to the anterior part of the patellar tendon and the surrounding fascia. Our results showed that the knee function score improved in the combined reconstruction group with reduced patellar height and extensor lag. He et al. showed that postoperative ISR was negatively correlated with MSTS scores (function, gait, walking), and that postoperative ISR was significantly correlated with knee extension lag [17]. We used three patellar height assessment indicators (ISR, BPI, CDI) and found that the postoperative patellar height in the combined reconstruction group improved, indicating that this reconstruction method can improve patellar position and extensor lag.

Infection is a common complication after proximal tibial replacement in most series (3–23%) [18]. Previous studies have demonstrated a reduction in infection rates after soft tissue reconstruction using an medial gastrocnemius flap, which was confirmed in our study. In addition, we found a reduction in early infection rates in the combined reconstruction group, suggesting that adequate soft tissue coverage is necessary to prevent early infection. However, this reduction may also be due to other changes or increased experience during the study period. Moreover, we did not find a difference in late infection rates between the two groups.

Our study has some limitations. First, because this reconstruction is rare and only large-scale case follow-ups are available in Asian countries, its general effectiveness in people of different ethnicities has not yet been proven. Second, we believe that the improvement in functional outcomes should be partly attributed to increased surgical experience with this reconstruction technique. In addition, the subpatellar/pseudopatinellar cut-off points were adopted from standard total knee arthroplasty because they have not yet been defined for EPR. However, we may have added supplementary information by measuring different patellar height indices (ISR, BPI, CDI), which best reflect the extensor mechanism. Apart from this, we included all patients undergoing proximal Hemiarthroplasty, so our design largely avoided selection bias. Finally, ROM and patellar Height were measured and recorded separately by two highly experienced doctors, which provided consistency over the 20-year study period but also introduced the possibility of bias.

In conclusion, soft tissue reconstruction of the proximal tibial hemiarticular prosthesis using a synthetic patch in conjunction with a medial gastrocnemius flap is an effective technological modification that restores the physiologic anatomy of the ligaments and provides effective coverage of the prosthesis. Patients who received a proximal tibial hemiarthroplasty with soft tissue reconstruction using a mesh combined with an medial gastrocnemius flap had a greater range of motion, better knee function and a reduced extensor lag. Therefore, on the basis of our results, we now recommend routine use of a mesh combined with an medial gastrocnemius flap for soft tissue reconstruction in patients undergoing proximal tibial hemiarthroplasty.
